- Reactome Pathway Database|url=https://reactome.org/|website=reactome.org|language=en-gb}}</ref> |}
== Approaches == The computational approaches used in cancer systems biology include new mathematical and computational algorithms that reflect the dynamic interplay between experimental biology and the quantitative sciences.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Carro|first1=MS|last2=Lim|first2=WK|last3=Alvarez|first3=MJ|last4=Bollo|first4=RJ|last5=Zhao|first5=X|last6=Snyder|first6=EY|last7=Sulman|first7=EP|last8=Anne|first8=SL|last9=Doetsch|first9=F|last10=Colman|first10=H|last11=Lasorella|first11=A|last12=Aldape|first12=K|last13=Califano|first13=A|last14=Iavarone|first14=A|title=The transcriptional network for mesenchymal transformation of brain tumours.|journal=Nature|date=21 January 2010|volume=463|issue=7279|pages=318–25|doi=10.1038/nature08712|pmid=20032975|pmc=4011561|bibcode=2010Natur.463..318C}}</ref> A cancer systems biology approach can be applied at different levels, from an individual cell to a tissue, a patient with a primary tumour and possible metastases, or to any combination of these situations. This approach can integrate the molecular characteristics of tumours at different levels (DNA, RNA, protein, epigenetic, imaging)<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Huang|first1=SS|last2=Clarke|first2=DC|last3=Gosline|first3=SJ|last4=Labadorf|first4=A|last5=Chouinard|first5=CR|last6=Gordon|first6=W|last7=Lauffenburger|first7=DA|last8=Fraenkel|first8=E|title=Linking proteomic and transcriptional data through the interactome and epigenome reveals a map of oncogene-induced signaling.|journal=PLoS Computational Biology|date=2013|volume=9|issue=2|pages=e1002887|doi=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1002887|pmid=23408876|pmc=3567149|bibcode=2013PLSCB...9E2887H}}</ref> and different intervals (seconds versus days) with multidisciplinary analysis.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pascal|first1=J|last2=Bearer|first2=EL|last3=Wang|first3=Z|last4=Koay|first4=EJ|last5=Curley|first5=SA|last6=Cristini|first6=V|title=Mechanistic patient-specific predictive correlation of tumor drug response with microenvironment and perfusion measurements.|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|date=27 August 2013|volume=110|issue=35|pages=14266–71|doi=10.1073/pnas.1300619110|pmid=23940372|pmc=3761643|bibcode=2013PNAS..11014266P}}</ref> One of the major challenges to its success, besides the challenge posed by the heterogeneity of cancer per se, resides in acquiring high-quality data that describe clinical characteristics, pathology, treatment, and outcomes and integrating the data into robust predictive models <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hill|first1=SM|last2=Lu|first2=Y|last3=Molina|first3=J|last4=Heiser|first4=LM|last5=Spellman|first5=PT|last6=Speed|first6=TP|last7=Gray|first7=JW|last8=Mills|first8=GB|last9=Mukherjee|first9=S|title=Bayesian inference of signaling network topology in a cancer cell line.|journal=Bioinformatics|date=1 November 2012|volume=28|issue=21|pages=2804–10|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/bts514|pmid=22923301|pmc=3476330}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Greenman|first1=C|last2=Stephens|first2=P|last3=Smith|first3=R|last4=Dalgliesh|first4=GL|last5=Hunter|first5=C|last6=Bignell|first6=G|last7=Davies|first7=H|last8=Teague|first8=J|last9=Butler|first9=A|last10=Stevens|first10=C|last11=Edkins|first11=S|last12=O'Meara|first12=S|last13=Vastrik|first13=I|last14=Schmidt|first14=EE|last15=Avis|first15=T|last16=Barthorpe|first16=S|last17=Bhamra|first17=G|last18=Buck|first18=G|last19=Choudhury|first19=B|last20=Clements|first20=J|last21=Cole|first21=J|last22=Dicks|first22=E|last23=Forbes|first23=S|last24=Gray|first24=K|last25=Halliday|first25=K|last26=Harrison|first26=R|last27=Hills|first27=K|last28=Hinton|first28=J|last29=Jenkinson|first29=A|last30=Jones|first30=D|last31=Menzies|first31=A|last32=Mironenko|first32=T|last33=Perry|first33=J|last34=Raine|first34=K|last35=Richardson|first35=D|last36=Shepherd|first36=R|last37=Small|first37=A|last38=Tofts|first38=C|last39=Varian|first39=J|last40=Webb|first40=T|last41=West|first41=S|last42=Widaa|first42=S|last43=Yates|first43=A|last44=Cahill|first44=DP|last45=Louis|first45=DN|last46=Goldstraw|first46=P|last47=Nicholson|first47=AG|last48=Brasseur|first48=F|last49=Looijenga|first49=L|last50=Weber|first50=BL|last51=Chiew|first51=YE|last52=DeFazio|first52=A|last53=Greaves|first53=MF|last54=Green|first54=AR|last55=Campbell|first55=P|last56=Birney|first56=E|last57=Easton|first57=DF|last58=Chenevix-Trench|first58=G|last59=Tan|first59=MH|last60=Khoo|first60=SK|last61=Teh|first61=BT|last62=Yuen|first62=ST|last63=Leung|first63=SY|last64=Wooster|first64=R|last65=Futreal|first65=PA|last66=Stratton|first66=MR|title=Patterns of somatic mutation in human cancer genomes.|journal=Nature|date=8 March 2007|volume=446|issue=7132|pages=153–8|doi=10.1038/nature05610|pmid=17344846|pmc=2712719|bibcode=2007Natur.446..153G}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mills|first1=GB|title=An emerging toolkit for targeted cancer therapies.|journal=Genome Research|date=February 2012|volume=22|issue=2|pages=177–82|doi=10.1101/gr.136044.111|pmid=22301131|pmc=3266025}}</ref>
== Applications == * Modelling Cancer Growth and Development Mathematical modeling can provide useful context for the rational design, validation and prioritization of novel cancer drug targets and their combinations. Network-based modeling and multi-scale modeling have begun to show promise in facilitating the process of effective cancer drug discovery. Using a systems network modeling approach, Schoerberl et al.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Schoeberl|first1=B|last2=Kudla|first2=A|last3=Masson|first3=K|last4=Kalra|first4=A|last5=Curley|first5=M|last6=Finn|first6=G|last7=Pace|first7=E|last8=Harms|first8=B|last9=Kim|first9=J|last10=Kearns|first10=J|last11=Fulgham|first11=A|last12=Burenkova|first12=O|last13=Grantcharova|first13=V|last14=Yarar|first14=D|last15=Paragas|first15=V|last16=Fitzgerald|first16=J|last17=Wainszelbaum|first17=M|last18=West|first18=K|last19=Mathews|first19=S|last20=Nering|first20=R|last21=Adiwijaya|first21=B|last22=Garcia|first22=G|last23=Kubasek|first23=B|last24=Moyo|first24=V|last25=Czibere|first25=A|last26=Nielsen|first26=UB|last27=MacBeath|first27=G|title=Systems biology driving drug development: from design to the clinical testing of the anti-ErbB3 antibody seribantumab (MM-121).|journal=NPJ systems biology and applications|date=2017|volume=3|pages=16034|doi=10.1038/npjsba.2016.34|pmid=28725482|pmc=5516865}}</ref> identified a previously unknown, complementary and potentially superior mechanism of inhibiting the ErbB receptor signaling network. ErbB3 was found to be the most sensitive node, leading to Akt activation; Akt regulates many biological processes, such as proliferation, apoptosis and growth, which are all relevant to tumor progression.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=Z|last2=Deisboeck|first2=TS|title=Mathematical modeling in cancer drug discovery.|journal=Drug Discovery Today|date=February 2014|volume=19|issue=2|pages=145–50|doi=10.1016/j.drudis.2013.06.015|pmid=23831857}}</ref> This target driven modelling has paved way for first of its kind clinical trials. Bekkal et al. presented a nonlinear model of the dynamics of a cell population divided into proliferative and quiescent compartments. The proliferative phase represents the complete cell cycle (G (1)-S-G (2)-M) of a population committed to divide at its end. The asymptotic behavior of solutions of the nonlinear model is analysed in two cases, exhibiting tissue homeostasis or tumor exponential growth. The model is simulated and its analytic predictions are confirmed numerically.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bekkal Brikci|first1=F|last2=Clairambault|first2=J|last3=Ribba|first3=B|last4=Perthame|first4=B|title=An age-and-cyclin-structured cell population model for healthy and tumoral tissues.|journal=Journal of mathematical biology|date=July 2008|volume=57|issue=1|pages=91–110|doi=10.1007/s00285-007-0147-x|pmid=18064465}}</ref> Furthermore, advances in hardware and software have enabled the realization of clinically feasible, quantitative multimodality imaging of tissue pathophysiology. Earlier efforts relating to multimodality imaging of cancer have focused on the integration of anatomical and functional characteristics, such as PET-CT and single-photon emission CT (SPECT-CT), whereas more-recent advances and applications have involved the integration of multiple quantitative, functional measurements (for example, multiple PET tracers, varied MRI contrast mechanisms, and PET-MRI), thereby providing a more-comprehensive characterization of the tumour phenotype. The enormous amount of complementary quantitative data generated by such studies is beginning to offer unique insights into opportunities to optimize care for individual patients. Although important technical optimization and improved biological interpretation of multimodality imaging findings are needed, this approach can already be applied informatively in clinical trials of cancer therapeutics using existing tools.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yankeelov|first1=TE|last2=Abramson|first2=RG|last3=Quarles|first3=CC|title=Quantitative multimodality imaging in cancer research and therapy.|journal=Nature Reviews. Clinical Oncology|date=November 2014|volume=11|issue=11|pages=670–80|doi=10.1038/nrclinonc.2014.134|pmid=25113842|pmc=4909117}}</ref> * Cancer Genomics * Statistical and mechanistic modelling of cancer progression and development * Clinical response models / Modelling cellular response to therapeutic interventions * Sub-typing in Cancer. * Systems Oncology - Clinical application of Cancer Systems Biology
== National funding efforts == In 2004, the US National Cancer Institute launched a program effort on Integrative Cancer Systems Biology<ref>NCI Cancer Bulletin. Feb 24, 2004. V1, 8. p5-6</ref> to establish Centers for Cancer Systems Biology that focus on the analysis of cancer as a complex biological system. The integration of experimental biology with mathematical modeling will result in new insights in the biology and new approaches to the management of cancer. The program brings clinical and basic cancer researchers together with researchers from mathematics, physics, engineering, information technology, imaging sciences, and computer science to work on unraveling fundamental questions in the biology of cancer.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gentles|author2=Gallahan|title=Systems biology: confronting the complexity of cancer|journal=Cancer Res|year=2011|volume=71|issue=18|pages=5961–5964|pmid=21896642|doi=10.1158/0008-5472.CAN-11-1569|pmc=3174325}}</ref>

{{Starbox begin}} {{Starbox observe | epoch=[[J2000.0]] ([[International Celestial Reference System|ICRS]]) | ra={{RA|20|32|25.78}}<ref name=2mass/> | dec={{DEC|+40|57|27.9}}<ref name=2mass/> | constell=[[Cygnus (constellation)|Cygnus]] }} {{Starbox character | class=WN 4-6<ref name=koljonen/> | appmag_1_passband=H | appmag_1 = 13.192<ref name=sbxy /> | appmag_2_passband=J | appmag_2 = 15.309<ref name=sbxy /> | appmag_3_passband=K | appmag_3 = 11.921<ref name=sbxy /> | variable [[X-ray binary]]<ref name=gcvs/> }} {{Starbox astrometry | radial_v={{val|208|113|127}}<ref name=koljonen/> | prop_mo_ra= | prop_mo_dec= | parallax= | p_error= | dist_pc = {{val|7,400|1,100|fmt=commas}}<ref name=mccollough/> | absmag_v={{val|-4.5}}<ref name=koljonen/> }} {{Starbox orbit | reference = <ref name=koljonen/> | period_unitless = 4.8 hours | k1 = {{val|379|124|149}} }} {{Starbox detail | component1 = WR | mass=8-14<ref name=koljonen/> | radius=<2<ref name=koljonen/> | luminosity={{val|209,000|93,000|64,000|fmt=commas}}<ref name=koljonen/> | temperature=40,000 - 50,000<ref name=koljonen/> | metal= | rotation= | age= | component2 = compact object | mass2 = {{val|2.4|2.1|1.1}}<ref name=zdziarski/> }} {{Starbox catalog | names= [[Variable star designation|V1521]] Cyg, 18P 57, [[Catalog of Galactic Wolf-Rayet stars|WR]] 145a, X Cyg X-3, [[ROSAT|RX]] J2032.3+4057, [[INTEGRAL1]] 118, 2U 2030+40, 3U 2030+40, 4U 2030+40.<ref name=sbxy/>}} {{Starbox reference | Simbad = Cygnus+X-3 }} {{Starbox end}}
'''Cygnus X-3''' is a [[high-mass X-ray binary]] (HMXB), one of the stronger [[X-ray binary|binary X-ray sources]] in the sky. It is often considered to be a [[Microquasar#Microquasar|microquasar]], and it is believed to be a [[compact object]] in a [[binary system]] which is pulling in a stream of gas from an ordinary [[star]] companion. It is the only known HMXB containing a [[Wolf-Rayet star]]. It is invisible visually, but can be observed at [[radio frequency|radio]], [[infrared]], [[X-ray]], and [[gamma-ray]] wavelengths.
==Observations== [[File:Cygnus X3.jpg|thumb|left|Cygnus X3 and its X-ray halo]] Cygnus X-3 is a prominent [[X ray]] source, with soft and hard x-rays both varying in intensity. Periods where the hard x-rays are at minimum intensity are known as soft states. It is less than half a degree from a [[gamma-ray]] pulsar, but is itself a weak gamma-ray source. It also shows periodic gamma-ray flares, apparently all occurring during the soft state.<ref name=becklin/><ref name=tavani/>
It is undetectable at visual wavelengths due to extreme [[extinction (astronomy)|extinction]] in the [[galactic plane]]. However, there is an [[infrared]] point source at its position.<ref name=koljonen/> Cygnus X-3 is also notable as one of the very few confirmed sources of [[ultra-high-energy cosmic ray]]s, with energies in the 100–1000 [[Electronvolt|TeV]] range.<ref name=zanin/>
Because of the variations in emission at various wavelengths, Cygnus X-3 has been given the [[variable star designation]] V1521 Cygnus.<ref name=gcvs/>
==Flares== Cygnus X-3 is notable for its intense X-ray emission and ultra-high energy cosmic rays, but it is also remarkable for its gamma-ray and radio flares during which it becomes the brightest radio source in the [[Milky Way]].<ref name=koljonen2018/> The gamma-ray flares apparently occur in the quiet radio period before a major radio flare.<ref name=becklin/><ref name=tavani/>
During the giant radio flares, a [[relativistic jet]] has been resolved within about {{val|14|ul=°}} of being aimed directly towards us.<ref name=koljonen2018/>
==Binary system== Cygnus X-3 shows consistent variations across all wavelengths with a {{val|4.8|ul=hour}} period. The nature of the infrared spectrum and the x-ray emission is interpreted as a [[binary system]] containing a [[Wolf-Rayet star|Wolf-Rayet]] (WR) star and a compact object. The {{val|4.8|u=hour}} variations have been interpreted as eclipses,<ref name=becklin/> but this is thought to be unlikely because there are not well-defined periodic dips in the brightness.<ref name=koljonen/>
The orbit of the binary system is not known accurately, other than the period. Therefore the masses of the components are not known accurately. Orbital analysis suggested that the mass of the compact object is less than {{solar mass|5|link=yes}}, probably around {{solar mass|2}}. It could possibly be a [[neutron star]] but is more likely to be a [[black hole]].<ref name=koljonen/> The combination of a WR star and a black hole would be the only known example.<ref name=lutovinov/>
While the combination of WR star and compact object would be unique, the WR component will itself almost certainly become a black hole very quickly by astronomical timescales. The expect [[supernova]] or possible direct collapse to a black hole is expected within a million years or so. However, modelling of the Cygnus X-3 system suggests it is most likely that the binary will be disrupted by any supernova event.<ref name=belczynski/>
The [[cosmic ray]] events from Cygnus X-3 had previously led to exotic proposals such as a star made of [[quark]]s,<ref name=quark/> but are now explained as being produced in the relativistic jet. The explanation for the unusual relationship between the x-rays and the gamma-ray and radio flares is that the compact objects produces jets along its axis of rotation, within the dense wind from the WR star. These jets evacuate a cocoon within the wind when entering the hard state, and are then quenched by the wind when entering the soft state. Flares are produced during the transition to the hard state as the jets are interacting with the dense wind.<ref name=koljonen2018/>
==Distance== Cygnus X-3 lies in the direction of the [[Cygnus OB2]] association in the [[Cygnus X (star complex)|Cygnus X]] complex, although it is much further away<ref name=mccollough/> Its distance can be estimated relative to Cygnus OB2 by studying the X-ray halo produced by dust between us and Cygnus X-3. The distance to Cygnus OB2 is not known precisely, but this method gives possible distances to Cygnus X-3 of {{val|3.4|u=kpc}} or {{val|9.3|u=kpc}}.<ref name=ling/>
There is a small X-ray source {{val|16|ul="}} from Cygnus X-3 that varies with the same period by a phase lag of about {{val|2.7|u=h}}. This is thought to be a [[Bok globule]] at approximately the same distance as Cygnus X-2. Using molecular line emission from this object, two possible distances are found to be {{val|6.1|0.6|u=kpc}} and {{val|7.8|0.6|u=kpc}}. A statistical mean is {{val|7.4|1.1|u=kpc}}.<ref name=mccollough/>

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = EQOS Energie | logo = Logo EQOS Energie.png | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = de | type = S.à r.l. | traded_as = | ISIN = | industry = [[Energy|Industrial Networks]]
[[Telecommunication]]
[[Traffic management]]
[[Construction equipment]]
[[Electrical engineering]] | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1920 | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Foetz]], [[Luxembourg]] | location_country = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Eric Mendel ([[CEO]])
Dr. Helmut Steurer ([[CFO]])[http://www.eqos-energie.pl/_press/dr-helmut-steurer-is-new-cfo-of-eqos-energie-holding “Dr. Helmut Steurer is new CFO of EQOS Energie.“] Holding Press release from EQOS Energie. Retrieved November 24, 2016. | products = | services = | revenue = 310 Million Euros[http://www.eqos-energie.com/en/company/group ''Company profile''], EQOS Energie. Retrieved November 24, 2016. | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | num_employees = ca. 2.200 | homepage = [http://www.eqos-energie.com/en// www.eqos-energie.com/en] }} '''EQOS Energie''' is a corporate group, based in [[Foetz]], [[Luxembourg]]. The company has more than 30 branches in eight countries. EQOS Energie specialises in railway and energy technology, overhead lines, communication technology and technical building services. Until August 2014, the company operated under the name ALPINE-ENERGIE.[http://www.triton-partners.com/media/archive/triton-new-owner-of-alpine-energie/ „Triton new owner of ALPINE-ENERGIE“], Press release from Triton. Retrieved November 24, 2016. EQOS is an [[acronym]] that stands for '''Excellent Quality Of Services''', and represents the brand promise.[http://www.eqos-energie.com/en/company/germany „EQOS Energie in Germany“], EQOS Energie. Retrieved November 24, 2016. EQOS Energie is owned by the European investment company Triton. == History == Founded as "ENERGIE-Gesellschaft für elektrische und industrielle Unternehmungen mbH" in [[Stuttgart]] by Wilhelm Blättchen in 1920, EQOS Energie has a nearly hundred-year-old company history.[https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=64784199 „Construction and Engineering: Company Overview of EQOS Energie Holding S.à r.l.“], Bloomberg. Retrieved November 25, 2016. Back then, the business segment was constituted by electrical and industrial enterprises. In 1978, the subsidiary "ENERGIE Lignes Hautes Tension" was founded in [[Luxembourg]]. 15 years later, the first working group (ARGE) combined their operations with the Austrian “ALPINE Bau GmbH" in a joint venture. In connection with ARGE, a 380-kV forwarding line was set up for the Austrian composite company as were the first steel towers for mobile radio networks. This resulted in the foundation of "ALPINE-ENERGIE Gesellschaft für elektrische und industrielle Unternehmungen GmbH", which is headquartered in [[Linz]], [[Austria]]. Due to the foundation of "ENERGIE-Gesellschaft für Leitungsbau und Kommunikationstechnik AG" in [[Berne]], the company expanded its business into [[Switzerland]]. Entry into the rail sector was marked by "ALPINE ENERGIE’s" launch in the catenary building sector at the Austrian [[St. Valentin]] main railway station in 1999. As a result, the catenary lines there were modernised. Three years later, the ALPINE Group took over the shares owned by Blättchen. While founding the "ALPINE-ENERGIE Holding AG" and "ALPINE-ENERGIE Deutschland GmbH", the business expanded and the company grew quickly. In 2006, the Spanish building group [[Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas|Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas (FCC)]] became majority shareholder of the ALPINE Group. In the same year, "SAG Kommunikationstechnik" was taken over. Through its acquisition of "SAG Kommunikationstechnik", the company extended its business in Switzerland and Austria. Between 2009 and 2011, "ALPINE-ENERGIE" companies were founded in [[Poland]], the [[Czech Republic]] and [[Hungary]]. In 2013, the FCC assumed ownership of ALPINE-ENERGIE, which became a subsidiary of FCC. Subsequently, the company was taken over by [[Triton Fonds]] in 2014. Since then, the long-established group member has conducted its business under the name of '''EQOS Energie'''. Following the turnaround, as one of the industry’s foremost suppliers, the company realigned its business model in 2015 to address growing market requirements. In a management buy-out, EQOS Energie retired in 2016 from the Swiss market and focused in all service areas on its eight core markets: [[Germany]], Austria, Luxembourg, [[France]], [[Belgium]], Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary. == Business Sector == EQOS Energie provides its customers with a wide range of solutions in five business sectors: railway and energy technology, overhead lines, communication technology and technical building services. Its range of activities include consulting, planning and construction as well as maintenance and optimisation. In addition to complete projects the company also offers individual services for various project stages. Concerning railway technology, EQOS Energie is specialised in the construction of catenary lines, signalling technology and technical equipment in the local and long-distance transport sector. The construction of switchgear and substations is the key expertise of the energy technology division. In the production and manufacturing processes, EQOS Energie plans, delivers, installs and maintains all technical facilities. Also, the company offers solutions in the areas of transport and lighting technology in Austria. Given changes in energy policy, EQOS Energie has taken over new construction and increased high-voltage network construction. As a nationwide full-service provider, EQOS Energie plans, constructs and maintains mobile communications and fixed networks. EQOS Energie focuses on technical equipment for buildings and the public sector in Poland and the Czech Republic. The spectrum of services extends from acquisition and construction to maintenance, modernisation and repair of commercial real estate and industrial plants.[http://www.finyear.com/Dr-Helmut-Steurer-is-new-CFO-of-EQOS-Energie-Holding_a36204.html "The Management Board of EQOS Energie now consists of Eric Mendel and Dr. Helmut Steurer"], financial and innovation all the year. Retrieved November 25, 2016. == References == [[Category:Engineering companies of Luxembourg]] [[Category:Electrical engineering]] [[Category:Telecommunications]] [[Category:Traffic management]] [[Category:Construction equipment]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2007}} '''Escapist fiction''' is [[fiction]] that provides a psychological escape from thoughts of everyday life by immersing the reader in exotic situations or activities.
The term is not used favorably, though the condemnation contained in it may be slight. Those who defend works described as escapist from the charge either assert that they are not escapist—such as that a [[science fiction]] novel's satiric aspects address real life—or defend the notion of "escape" as such, not "escapism"—as in [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s "[[On Fairy-Stories]]" and [[C. S. Lewis]]'s quotation, in his "On Science Fiction" of Tolkien's question of who would be most hostile to the idea of escape, and his answer: jailers.
Genres that can include elements of escapist fiction include: * [[Bodice ripper]]s/[[Romance novel]]s * [[Detective novel]]s * [[Fantasy fiction]] * [[Horror fiction]] * [[Pulp magazines|Pulp fiction]] * [[Science fiction]] * [[Spy novel]]s * [[Thriller (genre)|Thriller]]s
== See also == *[[Escapism]] *[[Formula fiction]] *[[Genre fiction]] *[[Pulp magazine]]s
[[Category:Fiction]] [[Category:Themes in works of fiction]]
{{lit-genre-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Event tree''' is an inductive analytical diagram in which an event is analyzed using [[Boolean logic]] to examine a chronological series of subsequent events or consequences. For example, event tree analysis is a major component of nuclear reactor safety engineering.<ref name="wang69">Wang, John '' et al.'' (2000). {{Google books|x4Ft7H_2Ik0C|''What Every Engineer Should Know About Risk Engineering and Management,'' p. 69.|page=69}}</ref>
An event tree displays sequence progression, sequence end states and sequence-specific dependencies across time.<ref>IAEA, [http://www-ns.iaea.org/downloads/ni/training/specific_expert_knowledge/psa-level1/III1_2_A%20Accident%20sequence%20modelling.pdf "Accident sequence modelling," p. 3.]</ref>
==Analytical tool== [[Event tree analysis]] is a logical evaluative process which works by tracing forward in time or forwards through a causal chain to model risk. It does not require the premise of a known hazard.<ref>National Research Council. (2002). {{Google books|pIKrHQDY-mgC|''Environmental Effects of Transgenic Plants: the Scope and Adequacy of Regulation,'' p. 5.|page=5}}</ref> An event tree is an inductive investigatory process.<ref name="wang69"/>
In contrast, the [[Fault tree analysis]] (FTA) evaluates risk by tracing backwards in time or backwards through a cause chain. The analysis takes as a premise a given hazard.<ref>National Research Council, {{Google books|pIKrHQDY-mgC|p. 4.|page=4}}</ref> FTA is a deductive investigatory process.<ref>Wang, {{Google books|x4Ft7H_2Ik0C|p. 58.|page=58}}</ref>
==Applications== An event tree may start from a specific initiator such as loss of critical supply,<ref>Compare [[Timeline of the Fukushima I nuclear accidents]]</ref> or component failure.<ref>Compare [[Northeast Blackout of 2003#Causes]].</ref>
Some industries use both fault trees and event trees. Software has been created for fault tree analysis and event tree analysis and is licensed for use at the world's nuclear power plants for [[Probabilistic Safety Assessment]].
==See also== * [[Event structure]] * [[Root cause analysis]] * [[Ishikawa diagram]] * [[Why-Because analysis]] * [[Failure mode and effects analysis]] (FMEA)
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
==References== * National Research Council (US), Committee on Environmental Impacts Associated with Commercialization of Transgenic Plants, Board on Agriculture and Natural Resources, Division on Earth and Life Studies. (2002). ''Environmental Effects of Transgenic Plants: the Scope and Adequacy of Regulation.'' Washington, D.C.: National Academy Press. {{ISBN|9780309082631}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/title/environmental-effects-of-transgenic-plants-the-scope-and-adequacy-of-regulation/oclc/231950695 OCLC 231950695] * Wang, John X. and Marvin L. Roush. (2000). ''What Every Engineer Should Know About Risk Engineering and Management.'' London: CRC Press. {{ISBN|9781420026962}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/title/what-every-engineer-should-know-about-risk-engineering-and-management/oclc/503045241&referer=brief_results OCLC 5030452]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Event tree}} [[Category:Quality]] [[Category:Reliability engineering]] [[Category:Risk analysis methodologies]] [[Category:Safety engineering]] [[Category:Systems engineering]]
